Summary: The proposal introduces a hierarchical planning framework that combines learned skill abstractions with symbolic planning for long-horizon robotic tasks. It addresses limitations of existing methods (HTNs and RL) by enabling efficient skill reuse, dynamic adaptation, and scalable planning. The proposed method includes skill abstraction learning, hierarchical planner integration, and online adaptation, with a comprehensive experiment plan covering validation, benchmarking, generalization testing, real-world deployment, and ablation studies.
Strengths: Ambitious and novel hypothesis integrating learned skills with symbolic planning.
Detailed and comprehensive proposed method with three distinct components.
Thorough experiment plan covering multiple aspects of validation and testing.
Weaknesses: Feasibility of integrating differentiable logic modules with VAEs is unclear and could introduce training instability.
Computational overhead of MCTS in real-time applications is not addressed, raising scalability concerns.
Scalability of the Bayesian nonparametric model for online adaptation is questionable in high-dimensional state spaces.
Lack of discussion on potential failure modes and mitigation strategies is a significant oversight.
Questions: How will the differentiable logic module ensure interpretable preconditions and effects for learned skills?
What are the computational limits of using MCTS for real-time planning in dynamic environments?
How will the Bayesian nonparametric model handle high-dimensional state spaces in real-world deployments?
What are the expected failure modes of the proposed system, and how will they be mitigated?
Limitations: Integration of differentiable logic with VAEs may introduce training instability.
MCTS may not scale well to very complex tasks with many subgoals.
Online adaptation may be too slow for real-time applications.
Generalization to entirely novel tasks (beyond shared subgoals) is untested.
